__data__.text:
Design of multi-layer Thermal Barrier Coating with cracks using finite element analysis

Anupam Purwar1 and Debiprosad Roy Mahapatra2

		1 Centre of Excellence in Hypersonics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India

		2Department of Aerospace Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India

			

ABSTRACT

Thermal barrier coating is essential for structural protection against excessive thermo-mechanical deformation and high heat flow leading to damage or melting. Ceramic based TBC develops complex cracks during the process of deposition which has significant effect on TBC performance. In this work, we report on a Finite Element Method (FEM) based evaluation of the effect of vertical cracks on stresses in a multi-layer Thermal Barrier Coating system (TBCs). We include the effects of thermal and mechanical property mismatch, thickness of top/intermediate/bond-coats and vertical cracks deliberately introduced in the ceramic top coat of TBC system. We analyze the effect of cracks on thermal mismatch induced stresses and the resulting thermal fracture under tension or compressive stresses. Various different crack geometries corresponding to different vertical crack lengths are modeled in a three dimensional representative volume element (RVE) of the TBC. The effect of the crack geometry viz. crack length, crack spacing and structural boundary conditions on the stress distribution have been examined to gain insight into designing a thermo-structurally reliant TBCs. Moreover, the effect of the interfacial stress and temperature in all ceramics layers are examined to evaluate the structural performance of TBCs with vertical. Also, a comparative study analyzing the effect of vertical cracks in a multi-layer TBCs with and without bond coat is carried out. The mechanical environment is simulated and analyzed here by finite element analysis using commercial software ANSYS. The thermo-mechanical behavior of multi-layer TBC under heat flux as high as 1.5 MW/m2 and pressure of 1.3 bars are investigated, towards finding the optimum parameters for crack geometry in the multi-layer TBCs. It is that a crack spacing of 125 μm and crack length of 300 μm is the most optimum for TBCs operational temperatures of 2000K.



Keywords: Thermal Barrier Coating; Crack; Lanthanum Zirconate; Yttria Stabilized Zirconia; Interface; Bond coat; Finite element analysis (FEA);.



 





Introduction

Thermal barrier coating (TBC) is an important material component in technology critical applications such as high temperature materials processing machineries, high energy infrastructure and future high speed aerospace transportation[1,2]. Another, prominent application area for TBCs is hypersonic transport, because hypersonic vehicles are exposed to intense, highly localized stagnation point heating and a severe thermal environment. Multiple shocks across the mixed compression air intake reduce the flow speed from hypersonic to supersonic and combustion exposes the scramjet to very high heat flux[3,4]. The wall temperatures of scramjet (propulsion system for hypersonic vehicles) for some designs can rise above 2000K, at such high temperature, strength and toughness of most metals degrades rapidly. This necessitates the use of protective mechanisms namely thermal barrier coatings (TBC) and thermal protection systems (TPS)  which shall reduce the heat flux experienced by hypersonic vehicle structure to protect  from  damage due to melting and from developing high thermal stress [5,6]. Recently, we have reported a multi-layer thermal barrier coating (TBC) system consisting of lanthanum zirconate (LaZr) and yttria stabilized zirconia (YSZ) layers for protecting metallic structure of scramjet engine during hypersonic flights. Experimental investigation of coating Inconel alloy substrate with LaZr has also been carried. But, it was observed that during heat treatment (sintering) of TBCs occurs, vertical cracks are generated due to generation of tensile stress in the TBCs, which has also been reported by Peng et al. [7]. Life prediction of TBC with cracks and fracture mechanics analysis of microcracks in thermally cycled thermal barrier coatings has been investigated by Busso et al [8] and Liu et al [9].

TBC layer are deposited by atmospheric plasma-spraying (APS) under high temperatures and it is inevitable that residual stress will be generated in the coating during this process. These initial machining residual stresses [10, 11] may evolve further and be more complicated when the APS-TBC services in the gas turbines under high temperature condition[12, 13]. The complicated residual stress distributions can result in large deformations and crack nucleation in coatings and, inevitably, severely influence the strength and lead to failure of components.

__data__.text:
These initial machining residual stresses [10, 11] may evolve further and be more complicated when the APS-TBC services in the gas turbines under high temperature condition[12, 13]. The complicated residual stress distributions can result in large deformations and crack nucleation in coatings and, inevitably, severely influence the strength and lead to failure of components. This necessitates the investigation of stress, strain and effect of crack in TBCs to improve the coating design for suitably modifying the production process and hence increase the TBCs service life.

It has also been reported that the vertical cracks are beneficial to thermal cycling performance of the coatings as it reduces the strain energy in the coatings[14,15], as well as reduce tendency of the ceramic to crack and buckle[16]. Nakahira et al. have reported vertical microcrack formation in the 2CaO2-SiO2-CaO·ZrO2 thermal barrier Coatings formed by plasma spraying process [17,18]. 

Vertical microcracks were deliberately introduced in the ceramic top coat of the plasma-sprayed coatings by Madhwal et al. to relieve thermal mismatch stresses[19].Weber et al. showed that vertical crack is beneficial in LZ TBC application due to enhanced thermo mechanical compliance[20,21]. The LZ based TBCs were deposited using the spray pyrolysis method, and thevertical cracks were introduced by decomposing the metal salt [22]. Moreover, the multilayer coating with vertical cracks was fabricated by the successive deposition and decomposition of multiple thin layers. Heat conductionwas small in this multilayer coating due to the generated cracks, and the thermal durability can be increased due to the increased thermo-mechanical compliance[21]. LZ coating has a lower fracture toughness than 8YSZ[23,24] and this leads to cracking at modest stress levels. 25].

The performance of commercial TBCs is generally done by air plasma spray (APS) and electron-beam physical vapor deposition (EBPVD) methods, which induce different microstructure development leading to different thermo-mechanical properties of the TBC. Through EBPVD columnar microstructure are produced with elongated intercolumnar pores aligned perpendicular to the substrate, increasing the coating’s compliance[26]. However, no reduction in the thermal conductivity of the coating is observed due normal orientation of the EBPVD pores with substrate [27]. APS produces TBCs having “splat” grains with inter-“splat” pores and micro-cracks parallel to the surface of the substrate [28]. Although such orientation of the pores, helps in reducing the thermal conductivity of the layer, but it causes coating spallation [29]. Karger et al. tried to increase the lifetime of TBCs deposited via APS by introducing dense vertical cracks (DVCs) in order to improve the strain tolerance [30]. However, for coatings with a density of less than 88% of theoretical, DVCs do not form and better compliance is obtained at the cost of low thermal conductivity[19].

Recently, nanostructured TBCs have been proposed with superior wear resistance and lower thermal conductivity compared to conventional coatings [31]. However, development of uniform nanostructured TBCs is difficult to achieve with the current commercial deposition methods, which use micrometer range powder particles. Padture et al. utilized solution precursor plasma spray (SPPS) technique to deposit nanostructured coatings[32]. SPPS produces low thermal conductivity and more durable coatings with ultra-fine splats, through thickness vertical cracks, embedded un-pyrolized particles, and uniformly dispersed nanopores [33]. Nevertheless, APS, SPPS, and EBPVD technologies are costly as well as complex [34], when equated to affordable wet chemistry deposition methods which facilitate the deposition of doped, multilayered, or graded coatings by utilizing liquid precursors.

Among wet chemistry deposition methods, spray pyrolysis offers thin or thick films coating deposition by adjusting the process parameters like substrate temperature to tailor the microstructure[35,36]. In particular while depositing thick coatings via spray pyrolysis, cracking occurs during the decomposition of the precursor salts in the deposited coatings and these crack patterns can be engineered to improve their durability under oxidation[37,38].

Although the above investigations have carried out rigorous experimental processing and have identified the failure modes under isothermal cyclic tests. However, an in-depth investigation on the effect of cracks in TBCs performance in relevant environment has not been pursued. Thus, there remains little knowledge on the effect of cracks on TBC behaviour under severe heat flux conditions as experienced in scramjet engines, gas turbines and IC engines.

__data__.text:
Although the above investigations have carried out rigorous experimental processing and have identified the failure modes under isothermal cyclic tests. However, an in-depth investigation on the effect of cracks in TBCs performance in relevant environment has not been pursued. Thus, there remains little knowledge on the effect of cracks on TBC behaviour under severe heat flux conditions as experienced in scramjet engines, gas turbines and IC engines. In this context, we have investigated a multi–layer TBCs with transverse (vertical) cracks as a scheme for mitigation of thermal stress. Transverse cracks are introduced in the first layer of multi-layer TBC system to reduce the residual stress at different interfaces of TBCs. Finite Element Model (FEM) has been developed to evaluate the effect of the cracks on stresses in the multi-layer thermal barrier coating system (TBCs). Various different TBC geometries with varying crack spacing and crack length are modeled for designing multi –layer TBC system.



Methods



(1-a)

(1-b)The thermo-mechanical environment has been simulated and effect of parameter related to crack dimensions and spacing are analyzed here by solving heat transfer and structural equilibrium equations. Based on our previous work, LaZr and YSZ materials have been selected for ceramic layer-1 and ceramic layer-2 respectively, their thickness has been determined based on operational temperature and shear stress considerations[2].

2.1 Geometry 

 The multi-layer thermal barrier coating system consisting of multiple ceramic layers with vertical cracks of width (w=10 µm), length (l) and inter-crack spacing (s) are the main design parameters, as shown in Fig. 1. In current investigation, crack lengths have been varied from 100-500 µm and crack spacing has been varied from 50-125 µm to understand the effect of vertical cracks in ceramic layer-1 on interfacial stresses.



(C)

Fig. 1. __data__.text:
2.2 Modeling and Simulation Approach

The thermal-structural analysis has been performed by employing the commercial code ANSYS which has been previously used by other researchers for similar analysis[39, 5]. The 3D model mesh of the TBC with metal substrate assembly is shown in Fig. 2. Similarly, multiple elements have been placed along the thickness direction to capture the temperature variation across difference material interfaces. Second order elements with mid-side nodes, SOLID90 “3D 20-node thermal solid” and SOLID 186 “3D 20-node hexahedral structural solid” have been used to discretize the structural domain. CONTA174 “3D 8-node surface to-surface contact” elements have been used to take into account contact phenomena between the joined components. The following assumptions have been made in performing finite element analysis:

1) Contacts at all interfaces have been considered as perfect, that is, all the interfaces have been assumed bonded;

 2) All layers are homogeneous and isotropic, there are no defects in each layer, and the interfaces between the two adjacent layers are flat without defects or wave characteristic; 

3) The creep and plastic deformation of TBC layers are negligible and have been neglected; 

4) All ceramic layers were assumed as linear elastic, crack can be initiated in the coating only when the stress exceeds yield stress, leading to coating failure; 

5) The air present in transverse cracks would be at thermal equilibrium with the TBC layer 1 material at time t=0 (start of aero-thermal heating). 

Two different cases have been considered for estimating temperature distribution in the TBC system. First case, convective heat transfer through crack walls has been neglected and in second case, convective heat transfer through crack walls has been modeled.

Transient thermal analysis (15 seconds of transient heating due to shock and hydrocarbon based fuel combustion) has been performed using ANSYS based FEM solver, by solving Equation 1. Wall temperature dependent heat flux has been applied on the exposed surface of ceramic layer1 and radiation boundary condition has been applied with emissivity 0.90 on outer surface of metallic substrate, as shown in Fig. 1. Radiation to ambient (Temperature=226K at 30 km) has been modeled. The initial temperature of the model, namely the temperature at the beginning of exposure, has been assumed to be equal to 300K. Temperature dependent material properties for Lanthanum Zirconate, yttria stabilized zirconia and Nimonic 90 alloy have been used for realistic temperature estimation. Heat flux (1.5 MW/m2) for scramjet 40 has been used as the boundary condition for upper surface of the top coat. 

The temperature obtained from transient heat transfer analysis has been mapped to the mesh of solid domain. The structural analysis has been performed using ANSYS based FEM solver to calculate the stresses, by solving Equation 2. Static structural analysis runs have been carried out with boundary conditions, as shown in Fig. 1. The walls of scramjet experience maximum pressure of 1.3 bars[41], accordingly, P=1.3 bars has been applied on the exposed surface of TBC Layer-1 and the side faces are provided displacement constraints (see Fig. 1). Temperature dependent material properties have been used for thermal and structural analysis for realistic temperature, stress and strain estimation [2].

	2.3 Finite element convergence study

Finite element convergence study has been carried out by considering a crack length of 500 µm and crack spacing of 100 µm. It is evident from Fig. 3. that by increasing the number of elements, the maximum displacement of ceramic layer 1 and maximum von-Mises stress at interface 1 changes and becomes constant as a grid size of 25000 elements is reached.  



Fig. 3. Finite element convergence study:  Variation of maximum von-Mises stress at interface 1 and maximum displacement of ceramic layer 1 as a function of mesh size (number of elements)

__data__.text:
Fig. 3. Finite element convergence study:  Variation of maximum von-Mises stress at interface 1 and maximum displacement of ceramic layer 1 as a function of mesh size (number of elements)



3. Results and discussion

The transient thermal analysis shows that introduction of vertical cracks does not significantly affect the temperature experienced by metallic substrate, when heat transfer through crack walls is ignored (see Fig. 4). This can be explained by the fact that volume of cracks is negligible as compared to overall volume of the multi-layer TBC system. But, there is a slight drop in maximum temperature of the top ceramic layer, which can be attributed to absorption of heat by air present in gaps of vertical cracks. On the other hand, considering heat transfer through transverse cracks clearly increases the maximum temperature experienced by TBC. Importantly, increase in length of crack leads to monotonic rise in maximum temperature experienced by TBC (see Fig. 6). 



Fig. 4. Variation of temperature across the thickness of multi-layer thermal barrier coating system (refer Fig. 1) calculated through transient thermal analysis with/without cracks  

The thermal and structural analysis (CTSA) shows that thickness of ceramic layer-1 and ceramic layer-2 affects the temperatures of TBC system as well as stresses at TBC system interfaces. The stresses and temperatures at each TBC interface reduce by optimizing the thickness of ceramic layer-1 and ceramic layer-2 in previous work. In current work, the effect of various geometric parameters like crack length (L) and crack spacing (s) has been investigated to understand their effect on temperature, overall displacement and stress experienced by TBCs. It has been found that vertical cracks help in reducing interfacial shear stress significantly at all the interfaces.

3.1 Effect of crack (ignoring heat transfer through cracks)

The effect of transverse cracks on interfacial shear stress has been investigated by introducing cracks of 20 μm width in the LaZr layer. However, the heat transfer through crack walls has been neglected in these analyses. It is found that introduction of cracks significantly reduces stress at all the interfaces, as summarized in Tables 2-4. This can be explained by the fact that thermal expansion relief is provided by the presence of transverse cracks.  In particular, the interfacial stresses vary non-linearly with crack width (Table 3) and a smaller crack length (300µm) relieves the stresses better than a full length crack (600µm) running through the entire thickness of ceramic layer 1 (Table 4).

__data__.text:
3.2 Effect of crack length (considering heat transfer through cracks)

	The boundary conditions play a crucial role in effecting the stress in the layers of thermal barrier coatings. We observed very high stresses of the order of 2-3GPa near crack tip when the faces of TBC layers are not allowed to expand. In this perspective, we have investigated the effect of allowing free thermal expansion of TBC layers with the side faces of metallic substrate fully constrained along all degrees of freedom. The temperature field is not affected by such change in structural boundary conditions, but, the stress field at interfaces of TBC and around crack tip varies significantly. 

	The increase in crack length produces a monotonic increase in temperature at the various interfaces, as shown in Fig. 5, due to increase in effective surface area available for heat deposition. Similarly, the stress at interface 2 increases monotonically with increase in crack length due to rising temperature at interface 2 (Fig. 6). However, the stress at interface 1 varies non-linearly with crack length. It increases when crack length is increased from 100µm to 200 µm. But, drops to 25.4 MPa for 300µm and then again increases with further increase in crack length (Fig. 6). This can be explained by the fact that increase in crack length increases the heat deposition, but, the vertical cracks have a stress relieving effect as well. Hence, an optimum vertical crack length needs to be selected, while tailoring the crack length during experimental coating/deposition of ceramic layers.


	

	

 Fig. 5. Variation of temperature at interface 1 and interface 2 of multi-layer thermal barrier coating system (refer Fig. 1) as a function of crack length, calculated through transient thermal analysis 

	

	

Fig. 6. Variation of stress at exposed surface of TBCs and interface 2 of multi-layer thermal barrier coating system (refer Fig. 1) as a function of crack length, calculated through thermo-structural analysis 

3.3 Effect of crack spacing (considering heat transfer through cracks) 

The effect of transverse crack spacing on interfacial shear stress has been investigated by introducing variable crack spacing of 50, 75, 100 and 125 μm in the LaZr layer. The change in crack spacing produces a monotonic decrease in temperature at the various interfaces, as shown in Fig. 7. This can be explained by the fact that the additional heat deposited through crack spreads over a larger material volume with increase in crack spacing. Similarly, the stress at interface 2 decreases monotonically with increase in crack spacing due to decreasing temperature at interface 2. However, the stress at interface 1 varies non-linearly with crack length. It increases when crack spacing is increased from 50µm to 75 µm (Fig. 8). But, decreases with further increase in crack spacing. This can be explained by the fact that effect of increased  heat dissipation with increase in crack spacing becomes dominant beyond crack spacing of 75 µm. Thus, a higher crack spacing has a stress relieving effect. Hence, an optimum vertical crack spacing needs to be selected, while tailoring the space between cracks during experimental coating/deposition of ceramic

 



Fig. 7. Variation of temperature at exposed surface of TBCs and interface 2 (substrate face) of multi-layer thermal barrier coating system (refer Fig. 1) as a function of crack spacing, calculated through transient thermal analysis

Fig. 8. Variation of stress at interface 1 and interface 2 of multi-layer thermal barrier coating system (refer Fig. 1) as a function of crack spacing, calculated through thermo-structural analysis

3.4 Effect of Bond Coat

The thickness values of ceramic layer-1 constituted of LaZr and ceramic layer-2 constituted of YSZ has been fixed at 0.6 mm 0.15 mm respectively along with a crack spacing of 125 μm and crack length of 300 μm, based on iterative thermo-structural analysis. Then, another analysis is carried out by introducing a bond coat between ceramic layer-2 and metal substrate to estimate interfacial and stress (Table 6). The introduction of bond coat creates interface 3 between bond coat and substrate faces. It can be clearly seen that temperature at different interfaces does not change significantly by introduction of bond coat, owing to its very small thickness of 50 µm. However, stresses at interface 1 reduce to half in presence of bond coat. Similarly, stresses at YSZ face of interface 2 reduce to one-third by introduction of bond coat. A comparison of the same has been made as shown in Table VI.  The stresses at YSZ-bond coat interface is higher compared to stress at YSZ-substrate interface, whereas bond coat-substrate interface experiences stresses as high as 450MPa at temperatures of 1100K.

	4. Conclusions	

The TBC design proposed in this work investigates the effect of transverse cracks on thermo-structural behavior of multi-layer thermal barrier coating. Multiple coupled thermal-structural analyses have been performed by varying parameters pertaining to crack width, length and spacing. Following salient observations have been made in the present work: 

The introduction of cracks helps in relieving interfacial stresses. But, the interfacial stresses vary non-linearly with crack width and a smaller crack length relieves the stresses better than a full length crack , when heat transfer through crack is ignored 

Crack length significantly affects interfacial stress values, when heat transfer through crack is considered.  Its effect on different interfaces of multi-layer TBCs is different and hence crack length optimization is required for effective stress management. 

Crack spacing of 125 µm and crack length of 300µm has been find to be the most optimum crack geometry in present investigation at  TBCs operational temperatures of 2000K. 

The introduction of bond coat in TBCs with crack helps in further reducing the interfacial stresses by 50 percent at interface 1 and 35 percent at interface 2.

It has been found that transverse cracks help in reducing interfacial stresses marginally and the effect of heat transfer modeling through cracks is essential to accurately estimate the stress and deformation of TBCs. Through rigorous computational investigation, we propose the use of multi-layer TBC system consisting of LaZr, YSZ with carefully tailored vertical cracks for effective protection of metallic airframe. Similar TBC system design can also be adopted for protecting metallic components of space vehicle, engines, gas turbines and rocket nozzles. Further work on the development of the proposed TBC system and its experimental investigation for other high temperature metal is being currently pursued.

__data__.text:
Acknowledgements:

The authors thank Centre of Excellence in Hypersonics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore for providing infrastructural support towards this work.

References

Combustion and Flame 2005, 142 (3), 187-196.

41.	Hyslop, P. CFD modelling of supersonic combustion in a scramjet engine. Australian National University, Canberra, Australia Canberra, Australia 1998.



To

Professor Hua-Tay Lin and Professor Monica Ferraris,

Editor-in- Chief

International Journal of Applied Ceramic Technology



Sub: Submission of an original Research Paper for review and publication



Dear Prof. Lin and Prof. Ferraris,

            We would like to submit the manuscript titled “Design of multi-layer Thermal Barrier Coating with cracks using finite element analysis” authored by Anupam Purwar and Debiprosad Roy Mahapatra, for the purpose of review for publication in “International Journal of Applied Ceramic Technology”. I would like to state that this manuscript is not published or under review in any other journal.

The manuscript reports a study on structural behaviour of multi-layer thermal barrier coating with cracks using rigorous Finite element analysis. While there are many reports on development and fabrication of thermal barrier coatings using Air plasma spray, Spray pyrolysis and their experimental characterization. However, an investigation adopting an integrated approach to study the influence of vertical crack in a multi-layer thermal barrier coating is uncommon. Moreover, the present work reveals the effects of crack parameters like crack length and crack spacing on substrate temperature and stresses at different interfaces of multi-layer coating. Also, a comparative study analyzing the effect of vertical cracks in a multi-layer TBCs with and without bond coat is carried out. 

The present work simulates the thermo-mechanical environment using commercial software ANSYS under heat flux and pressure as experienced in high temperature combustion systems like scramjets, towards finding the optimum parameters for crack geometry in the multi-layer TBC. Our analyses show that that a crack spacing of 125 μm and crack length of 300 μm is the most optimum for TBC operational temperatures of up to 2000K.

The current length of the manuscript is close to 7600 words considering all the figures, tables, references. We have broadly reviewed the reported literature on thermal barrier coatings and carefully provided details on computational modeling including mesh convergence studies. This would enable the readers to get a holistic understanding of our work as well help them conceive the comprehensive computational scheme employed in the present work.

Hope you will find the manuscript interesting and worth publishing in your esteemed journal.

Sincerely yours,

Anupam Purwar 

Centre of Excellence in Hypersonics

Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore –560012

Karnataka, INDIA.

Corresponding author

__data__.text:
0, what is i venture?
, I-Venture @ ISB is a program that focuses on fostering entrepreneurship and nurturing start-ups at the Indian School of Business (ISB). It administers business incubators that provide support for entrepreneurship from the initial stages to scaling up. The program aims to facilitate the conversion of start-ups into profitable entrepreneurial ventures through multidisciplinary research initiatives and academic programs that strengthen the entrepreneurial mindset.

I-Venture @ ISB offers specific programs catering to entrepreneurs and ventures at all stages. The program works towards creating a robust ecosystem of mentors, venture capitalists, and academicians to support start-ups in reaching the market and achieving growth.

Additionally, I-Venture @ ISB has various Innovation Centers like DLabs, AIC ISB, DIRI, and TRICOR. These centers play a crucial role in supporting and nurturing entrepreneurial ventures.

The program also has an Advisory Board consisting of prominent individuals from the industry who provide guidance and support to the start-ups. The team behind I-Venture @ ISB includes experienced professionals and faculty members who are dedicated to driving entrepreneurship and innovation at ISB.

Overall, I-Venture @ ISB is a comprehensive initiative that aims to inspire, invest, and innovate in the field of entrepreneurship, creating a conducive environment for start-ups to thrive and succeed., nan, 0.14004914004914, 0.4789915966386555, 0.0699300699300699, 0.2197802197802197

__data__.text:
, ISB, through its I-Venture initiative, organizes a variety of events to support entrepreneurs and startups. Here are some of the events planned or that have taken place:

1. **Knowledge Series (I-Venture @ ISB) | Episode 4**
   - **Date:** August 21, 2023
   - **Description:** This event focuses on entrepreneurship, covering various aspects such as business planning, financial management, marketing, sales, and team building.

2. **I-WIN 2.0**
   - **Date:** October 27, 2023
   - **Description:** I-Venture @ ISB's Women of Innovation Program aims to provide acceleration support to women-founded/co-founded start-ups by guiding entrepreneurs through their scaling-up journey.

3. **I-Mentor @ ISB | Session 2**
   - **Date:** October 3, 2023
   - **Description:** This session involved mentors engaging with startups to understand their challenges and provide guidance.

4. **I-Speak @ ISB | AIC ISB Mohali**
   - **Date:** January 16, 2023
   - **Description:** An event where founders like Vishal Jindal and Nikhil Doda shared their insights, moderated by Dr. Saumya Sindhwani from the Indian School of Business.

5. **I-Connect @ ISB Powered by DBS Bank**
   - **Date:** July 25, 2022
   - **Description:** A networking event at ISB Mohali Campus to facilitate interactions within the entrepreneurial ecosystem.

6. **I-Hustle @ ISB: Pitch Day at MFABulous 2022**
   - **Date:** August 27, 2022
   - **Description:** A pitch day event as part of MFABulous 2022, where entrepreneurs presented their ideas.

7. **I-WIN Demo Day**
   - **Date:** September 24, 2022
   - **Description:** A Demo Day marking the completion of the 1st cohort of the I-WIN Acceleration program.

8. **Fireside Chat with Upasana Kamineni Konidela and Prof Bhagwan Chowdhry**
   - **Date:** September 24, 2022
   - **Description:** A fireside chat discussing entrepreneurship and leadership as part of I-Venture @ ISB's one year anniversary celebration.

These events showcase the diverse range of activities and support provided by ISB through the I-Venture initiative to nurture entrepreneurship and innovation., nan, 0.1925465838509316, 0.6702702702702703, 0.085613415710503, 0.3674242424242424
